For one, they have no armrests, forcing one to fold one's arms across one's chest for the entire show, or otherwide risking put one's arms (hands) somewhere where they shouldn't be. Secondly, the backrests are at the wrong angle, putting so much strain on the lower back that after a few songs I was ready to leave (only the great music kept me in my seat).  So watch out. If you have any back problems, find another venue; you will hate these seats.
One of my favorite places to go. A hidden gem.You can find cheap, great shows by talented musicians. The audience is always cool, calm, and respectful.

My review is based on the Music class "de la Cuna a la Luna" I attend on Thursdays. It is led by Jorge and is a Spanish immersion class in which he exposes the children to all kinds of musical instruments and songs from latin culture. I am a musician myself and educator myself, and I give this class two thumbs up! It is great for the music, stimulation, as well as the Spanish-speaking environment. (Jorge is bilingual so no worries if you aren't fluent!) It is also well-priced. The only negatives would be I do have to work at finding a parking spot before class. Be sure to give a little time for that. 2nd, I have a hard time getting them to answer the phone when I call with a question. You are better off emailing.It is a fantastic facility for classes- lots of clean, well-lit rooms. The bathrooms are easy to access and clean, too. (That's important with kiddos!)The lady who greets you at the entrance to the building is really sweet and friendly, too.
Great concept. Big, clean comfy space. Good coffee. Wholesome fun in every way. Loved the House Jacks!!!!!

Great acoustics/sound. Smallish, still new interior which has comfortable padded chairs.Not as vibrant as it could be and the clientale tends to be ages 50+.They should try to entice and win over the younger crowd more with a more balanced calendar of more youth oriented acts.I'm not saying older isn't great but I want more balance of folk.
I went to the West Coast Songwriter competition at the Freight last night.  It was great!  the sound quality was beautiful and I love the lighting.

What a great music venue! So relaxed and open, feels like you're among family. The diversity and uniqueness of music shows is quite impressive. From bluegrass to classical and everything in between... there is certainly something here for everyone to enjoy and discover.  Check out their calendar: http://www.thefreight.org/eventCan't wait to return, get comfy, and experience some sounds I've never heard ...
This is a great venue to see a band.  I saw Girlyman there and it felt like we were almost touching them.  They serve no booze, so be warned.Can't wait to go see Girlyman there again!

I really enjoyed the performances that were held at this place. I performed my very first open mic at this venue and the acoustics are absolutely fantastic. Coming back just to be in a wonderful hall of  sound. Look forward to performing an original next. Thank you to my dear friend jane l. who encouraged me and helped me muster enough courage to do this! O, and this place has good hot cider, but $2 for a small cup.

Great venue for a concert. Small enough to be very intimate even when filled to capacity, yet big enough to feel like you're at a real concert. I love that they provide a stage for acts that don't normally get the attention from other venues. This is a great place.

THIS IS MY FAVORITE PLACE TO GO TO FOR LIVE MUSIC IN BERKELEY. as if that said everything. I saw my dear friend at open mic, and I was ROCKED. yes by her.. but the ACOUSTICS let you swim and MELT in talent.. it is AWESOME. the family-esque feel creates a super open safe space for artists and a breeding ground for community. the pricing is awesome. go to an open mic stay til the end, and FREE TICKETS to shows.. I saw and discovered my NEW FAVORITE there- Joy Kills Sorrow. Just when you think music is breathing its last breathe.. you find a revival of sounds and hidden gems at this place. I heart you. so sad I didn't find you sooner my dear freight.

beautiful space, cozy atmosphere, great acoustics, friendly staff.  performed at their open mic for the first time last night and the crowd was mostly older mostly white so i felt a little out of place but they were all very sweet and encouraging.  no booze which has its upsides (no drunken tomfoolery) and its downsides (no drunken tomfoolery).  but it makes for some good clean fun and attracts people who are genuinely there to enjoy the music.  i was a little turned off by the $4.50 - 5.50 cover for the open mic but they give you a free ticket at the end of the night to any show of your choice in the following weeks which more than makes up for it.  i'll be back for sure.

Saw Dar Williams here on 8/1.  My husband is a huge fan and took me along for the ride.  We're from LA, and have been to quite a few acoustic music venues all over the country, so we have some context by which to judge.Positives:- Decent, not awesome, sound.  Vocals mixed too low.  Didn't knock my socks off like the acoustics at Old Town School in Chicago or McCabes in LA. But I am nitpicking; it was solid.- Good crowd.  What's the definition of a good crowd?  They shut the f*** up when the artist is playing.- Great sight lines.  Not a bad seat in the house. The chairs are  comfortable, too.- Close to BART.  It's a block and a half away from the downtown Berkeley station.  Whoever said it was a trek from the BART through a sketchy neighborhood ought to visit Detroit or Baltimore and get a reality check.Negatives:- A coffeehouse should have good coffee.- Leave the babies at home.  Why why do parents insist on bringing noisy babies to concerts.  I love kids, but it's annoying to pay $60.00 for tickets and listen to baby noise. Next time it happens I am going to ask for my money back.  It's selfish for those parents to (1) bring their kids out late at night. The concert ended at 11:00.  Those parents should be ashamed of themselves.  Kids need to be sleeping in their beds and (2) it's rude to the other patrons sitting around them.  Enough already!- No bar.  It's nice to enjoy great music with a beer or glass of vino. Note to management: put the bar in the lobby, not in the performance hall.  And cut off sales when the artist plays.If you like folk / americana music this is a really nice venue and the people who run it have a commitment to the artists and and fans.

Freight & Salvage is one of my very favorite live music venues in the Bay Area. It's an accessible and comfortable space and they bring in a number of "big" artists in the folk and bluegrass scene. Rhonda Vincent, Girlyman, Dar Williams... It's very easy to get a good seat at most concerts and, in fact, there isn't really any bad seating. I will say that I miss the homey feel of the old Freight & Salvage - as if we were congregating in someone's old barn for a concert where the musicians and audience practically talked to each other. Maybe they need a little more creative lighting. I don't know. But it's still a great deal and their programming is just great.
Fun place to go for open mic.  Comfortable seats, easy access, free if you're with someone singing or playing (we were, yay Ed!), and good acoustics.  No alcohol but the coffee was good......

We were in the Bay Area to see the Giants' opening home game and decided to catch Robbie Fulks at the Freight and Salvage in Berkeley.  Fulks is damned good.  Think Hank Williams' vocals, Doc Watson's flatpicking, Todd Snider's humorous/serious songwriting, and David Letterman's ironic, biting commentary between songs.I liked the Freight & Salvage as a music venue -- great sound and intimate seating. Warning: They don't serve alcohol.  (For a real treat, sneak in a flask of hooch, spike your coffee or peppermint tea right in front of everyone, and watch the judging commence.) The audience at Freight & Salvage reminded us of the public radio hosts of the Saturday Night Live skit called "The Delicious Dish."  "Good times.""Yeah......good times."   The kind of audience that appreciates it when a group of Puritan Connecticut Yankees like The Weavers turns a darkly ominous song like Leadbelly's "Goodnight, Irene" -- which is about sexual obsession evoked by jailbait, with suicide and murder as potential side-dishes -- into a lullaby.  Replace "I'll get you in my dreams" with "I'll see you in my dreams."  Good times......good times.
The best place in the entire SF Bay area to see live music!

Okay, for starters I never thought I would go see americana/ folk bands, but we had a great time!  We went to see Dr. K's Home Grown Roots Revue series: Misner & Smith, Three At Last, Family Lines.  No, we aren't aging hippies (power to the peaceful), though one of our group is a country fan, the rest of us came up on punk and hardcore.  Nevertheless, we had so much fun here and will definitely be back.  Reasonably priced at about $14, comfortable seating, pretty good acoustics, clean, friendly, good decor.  At first I have to admit I was a bit skeptical about a music venue sans alcohol, but we had a blast anyways!

Oh how fun!  More than community theater.  Less than super high budget performances. Serves coffee, tea, cookies (vegan ones too!), hot cocoa, and the like along with your performance which makes you feel very cozy.The chairs are VERY comfortable and clean, and the whole place is classy modern with an environmentally friendly twist.I went with my family to see "Dr. K's Home Grown Roots Revue series: Misner & Smith, Three At Last, Family Lines-harmony-rich americana/folk music"  The premise of the show is that if you like one band, you'll like them all.  I found this to be very true.  By far my favorite group was Misner & Smith (http://www.reverbnation.com/misnerandsmith)Their CD is in my car that plays over and over until I get to my destination.  They have 2 albums and I have the first.  The Dr. K Show was a great place for all the groups to showcase their music and the audience was really receptive and supportive and in general it was a lot of fun.  Tickets were really reasonable for the high quality of experience, $14.50 pre-sale, $15 at the door.  We had no trouble getting tickets at the door.  Only draw back (as is normal for Berkeley) is parking, but there are a few lots near by and I think it is worth the extra $5 to not be hunting for Downtown Berkeley street parking.

Ok. So.  This one will tip my street cred because I write positive reviews for some places that others disdain, but I do not mind.Freight and Salvage is a coffee house that has enjoyed 3 locations since its inception in 1968.  It is now directly across the street from Berkeley Rep just a block or so from Shattuck Downtown Berkeley Bart.The new setting is classy, but it still retains a warmish feeling inside, with comfort and a great staff.There is a young woman with short hair who was worth the price of our tickets to see Glen Phillips and Grant Lee Phillips last evening, for she is one of the front staffers and more talented on stage than many performers in this wonderful world.  Funny and good timing in her delivery of the description how she loves that the new carpet doesn't surround her with a burst of dust when she goes to the microphone.  I loved her description of the upcoming events and the show had not even begun.  The bar serves a limited menu but home made cookies and brownies, beverages.  We were very very pleased that halfway through the show it was mentioned that people should not be videtotaping.  We had one woman just in front of us who almost taped Glen's entire show.  We hoped her battery would die but alas, she has some sort of future digital device that keeps on giving....The restrooms are in two locations, plenty for everyone.Everything is convenient and clean and the staff extremely knowledgeable and helpful.  I highly recommend this venue as a newly done coffee house that with its warmth and the enthusiasm of the returning fans, makes up for not being a small typical coffee house spot.  The doors were opened well before 7, they allowed people to choose seats for the 8pm show, and I have already invited others to join me for some shows. Bear with me as I have never been to F&S nor have I heard the two artists in the show, having been living overseas for years in the 80s and 90s.  My dear cousins turned me on to both of them, who were amazing performers, and of course I have fallen in love with their music and turned to my iTunes post haste.The intimacy came in here, not related to the newness of the new digs, but to the design which was so well crafted to have a closeness for the audience and the performer for interactions.  There is a comic component to the Phillips/Phillips performers that was rendered very very effective because the people are up close.One comment I would make is that it appeared some very young people behind us were not at all reprimanded for disrupting the program.  All of Berkeley was outside for them but they chose to stay and no one approached them because we were all so interested in seeing the show.Walking to Bart from my place at Lake Merritt and from Bart in Berkeley to the theatres represents a whole new way to spend my money and I surely will.

There aren't too many places like this around, a smallish venue that serves coffee/tea and has really good live music.The Freight's new digs kind of takes it out of the "smallish" category, but that's easily forgotten.  Its new arrangement, in theatre-style seating, however, means that if you bring coffee back, you have nowhere to put it, unless you're sitting right next to one of the rare tables.Oh, another note:  they say on their website that they open doors at 7pm.  They don't.   Also, their sound system, while brand-spanking new and totally up-to-date, seems temperamental.  I could tell that the onstage monitors weren't working well (if there were any), because the pianist had a hard time following the guitarist.  I imagine they'll work those issues out.I suspect every seat is great, and for live entertainment, I found it fairly cheap.  I noticed, however, that it wasn't sold out, and because of all the new seats, I suspect they rarely sell out.  They somehow need to find a way to get butts in the seats.The chairs, by the way, are a far cry from what they had before:  they're padded and wide enough for even the larger butts.

We went on a Friday to see Chris Smithers, with Tim Erikson as the opening act. The new hall looks modern, although the reclaimed boards stuck on the side walls try in vain to give a rustic feel. The seats were very comfortable. We arrived way early and sat in the front row. The sold out show was fine. Surprisingly, I liked the opening act a lot more than Mr. Smithers.The crowd is mostly aging white Berkeley, with Birkenstocks and grey pony tails. The were polite and restrained in their response to the music, tapping their feet, but no dancing. I get the feeling they would ask you to leave if you did that. The line for the coffee bar was too long, so I can't comment on the quality there.  The acoustics were good (I listened a while from the back) throughout the hall. If you like the artists, this is an ok place to see them. You will be surrounded by old hippies.

My trio came out for the first open mic hosted at the new location. This is by far the nicest open mic venue to play at. Hands down the nicest stage I've played on. The people are nice. Acts are a good variety mostly acoustic and a lot of original material. Some better than others. Suzanne was a nice host and moved things along very well. Would have been a 5-star if it weren't for the following. Lighting - Too bright on stage you can't see your audience. Sound - Great equipment. I'm sure they'll learn how to use it. There was no or little monitor mix on stage yet they have 4 or 5 monitors. This made it hard to hear ourselves esp our vocalist and we had an electric bass which couldn't be heard at all on stage. Bass players bring your own amp or you won't hear your part.Only two inputs for instruments but there were plenty of mics on stage. Don't move 'em around though. They don't seem to like that. You have to pay to get in which is fine esp since it is a first class stage. The coffee and snacks are a little pricy they could consider lowering those items since people are already paying to get in. I'm not much of an open mic fan but this place has the potential to be one hell of a place to get some original talent exposed. They could bring a good draw but just need to work on the stage sound a bit. The sound from the audience's perspective was fine.

Ok.  I know this post is a bit much, but it's one of those I just have to share.I love all kinds of live music, from folk to blues to thievery.  And I appreciate musicians who continue to play music because they love it.  Maybe my friend and I went on an off night (a Friday?).   And maybe we had suddenly slipped into a parallel universe.  But oh my GOD!  I don't appreciate being charged a cover to sit on folding chairs, with no bar, to watch hippie dudes playing out of tune guitars singing off key the most terrible rendition of songs they seemingly wrote while stoned - at age 12. The freakiest part?  The entire crowd (ahem - crowd of 30 people) was nodding along and slapping their knees and getting into it.  It was the first time in my life I thought I was on candid camera... that the joke was on us... and this was all a ruse. Once I realized that it wasn't, I was seconds away from (again, another first in my life) the loudest and most inappropriate outburst of laughter in the middle of somene's performance.  The feeling of my body convulsing in uncontrollable laughter began to take over my system, but I was torn between that and the rudeness of getting up *in the middle* of his performance and being just as obvious.So I leaned into my friend's shoulder and commenced what I've coined the "snaugh" - which is a sneeze, a cough, and a violent laugh all mashed together.  I was horrified.  I couldn't stop.  I was crying.  I was helpless.  By the time the song was over, I was hysterical, in the craziest sense of the word, and we barely made it outside before I fell to the ground in a display of entirely involuntary and uncontrollable fits of hyperventilating laughter and diaphragm spasm, and near asphyxiation. My rational mind was awed by my inability to take over the controls of my own physical system, and to this day I have not had an experience remotely close - and I doubt I ever will.

Can't believe I've never been here before.  Went to see a former employer play with his new band.  A great time to get together with old colleagues and catch up and see someone you knew in another context, perform and do it well!  The whole vibe of the place is great.  Easy going, happy, positive.  I like that it's a non profit also. It's reasonably clean, funky seating, but a great place.  Nice people!!!

The Freight and Salvage rocks.  They are a small local and independent music and coffee house.  They support community and independent arts. I've seen several shows there - the acoustics are fantastic and the ambiance is sweet - there are white holiday lights strewn about the interior of the barn-like room.  It's simple and charming.  I hope they maintain the charm at the new location - they will be relocating closer to downtown Berkeley this fall.  There is a delicious coffee bar for snacks and cocoa, coffee, tea or cider.  It's street parking only so can be a bit tricky; take transit, bike, or ride-share if you can.  And enjoy the show.
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Freight & Salvage Coffeehouse", "AuthorName": "Anj M.", "AuthorLocation": "San Luis Obispo, CA"}

ReviewContent: Typical Berkeley...hippy and local! You enter through ply board doors to a room filled with thrift store torn diner seats. Went to see Kenny White (a political musician) and had a great time.  It's a great location to see local artists, poetry readings and just music.  Would go again.VEggie Friendly: Yes- They have pastries, finger snacks and a coffee bar.

This is my favorite place to see live music these days.  I like to tag along with my husband to see the best open mic talent that you can find in the East Bay, usually on a Tuesday night. Great coffee and delicious cookies and brownies brought to you by Zoe's Cookies. Yum! Lots of different types of music to find here and people seem completely respectful of that talent. Maybe it also helps that they don't serve alcohol! Ha Ha

The open mic here in my opinion is the best. I have been to a shit load of them up and down CA and by fare you meet the nicest people who actually listens to you. I go to shows when I can at this place they usually ave great guys working to sound.

I saw The Animators and Vienna Teng here. Honestly, I have no idea how I managed to find this place with my friend. It was when I didn't know the area well yet, and my friend and I took bart from Fremont, got off Ashby, and managed to wander through the darkest creepiest neighborhood to find this place. We were also stopped by a group of about 8 teenage boys (who were all taller than us); although we were older than them (we were 19 at the time), it was still a bit scary just because it was at night, we had no idea where we were, and we were merely tiny little Asian girls.I remember this place being super small and informal. The set up was just a bunch of chairs in rows. Very cramped space.

Every single time I go to the freight I love the music and I am thankful there is a venue right here in Berkeley for music that would normally not have a huge audience.I am hopeful that when construction is done on the new location and the Freight moves further towards campus on Addison they will be able to maintain their rustic feel and access to bands who may have smaller draws.  At the same time I fear that the larger & more expensive venue will change the atmosphere and force the Freight to focus on bands with larger audiences.  This would be unfortunate, but we shall see.The concern notwithstanding, it will be nice to have better seats.  :-)

It almost doesn't matter what show you pick to attend, you will see and hear a good show in an intimate atmosphere. There will be some humor involved, and some electric guitar may even be heard.But, don't fear the banjo.  Really- get beyond that.The seating is not the most comfortable for my 6' 2" frame, but there is always an intermission, so I survive.  Country boys can survive.

Years ago my father was the MC on open mic night at the freight. Sopping wet wit, a great stylized fingerpicking blues/bluegrass and an old beatup looking guild guitar that reverberated out 35 years of music every time you thumped it. He fit the freight just about perfect.Berkeley houses a lot of great folk/blues/bluegrass/etc talent and the freight is one of the places they gather (performers also come from far and wide). So the music is really top notch. One more side note... my dad used to collect up a bunch of the brownies and cookies at the end of the night, head on over to Flints BBQ and trade a bunch of them for a robs/links plate. Then he would ramble home and find me still awake, at which point we would share a BBQ and Brownies. Obviously nostalgia probably clouds the hell out of my judgment on the brownies, but those dry little light brown nuggets taste like ambrosia somewhere in the depths of my mind - especially dipped in hot sauce.

This is a great place to see live music.  Very small, great snack bar, wonderful sound.  I am always entertained when I go here.  Love the line up.  I love taking my son to the shows here.  The audience is very welcoming to kids.

It was my wife's b-day last night, so I surprised her by taking her to The Freight to hear some bluegrass.  Doors open at 7:30 and there was a decent line down the street for advance ticket holders. Nell Robinson and the Red Levels has a good Berkeley following, and they packed the house.  Their mandolin player can pick with the best of them. The occupancy maximum is about 240, and they exceeded it, I think. Folding chairs are pretty uncomfortable, but there are a few that are padded, which the cheesy patrons swipe and re-arrange before the show.  I assume the new venue in downtown Berkeley will be more comfortable..that's the only complaint anyone could make.

Freight & Salvage is definitely one of those "Only in Berkeley" type venues - a non-profit, community based coffee house that also happens to host some amazing live music. The acoustics are awesome, the coffee...not so much.  If you are the type of person that must drink while at a show you might want to look elsewhere - this is a dry venue and as much as I like to drink (ok, I LOVE to drink) it was refreshing to see a sold out house there to enjoy the music instead of shouting out "FREEBIRD!!!" drunkenly every five minutes.While I don't see myself becoming a regular here (after all, it is across the bridge) I wouldn't hesitate to return to Freight & Salvage to catch one of my favorite artists.

This is a small, intimate venue with no bad seats in the house... there are even some random tables scattered here and there for putting your coffee, herbal tea, hot apple cider, and sweets down on... You should know this place is dry (as in no booz), so something to keep in mind. GREAT place to see music you love.

I love this place.  It makes me sad that they're moving to another location.   It's a great space.  It reminds me of some of the performance spaces in downtown Manhattan.  I saw a big band concert here this past Saturday and loved it.  First time seeing a big band concert,  I learned quite a bit of history that night, and the music was great.  It's an intimate space so there's no bad seating.  We sat in the second row, the seats were comfortable, we even had a table nearby for our drinks.  They sell coffee, teas (herbal and caffeinated), cookies, etc.  I found everyone very helpful and friendly.  it was a lot of fun and a great evening.

If I had to choose between seeing Cold Play on a jumbo tron in an ice hockey 'pavilion' or seeing Dan Bern at a coffee house and asking Dan from the front row, 'Dan, play God Said No' and then have him smile and say  'No' and getting a laugh from the crowd... hmmm which would I choose?I don't know, that's a tough one.

Beautiful!! I had the pleasure and honor of playing here last night, opening for Blame Sally (an amazing local band whom I adore). I had heard this place is legendary, with amazing sound and history to match. It surpassed my greatest expectations - gorgeous sound system, and a warm, cozy vibe. It isn't really what I'd call a coffeehouse in the traditional sense, but it does have a coffeehouse atmosphere, despite it's large size. It seats 250 people, and it seems everyone has a great view of the stage. Gorgeous venue, both for the performer and for the listener.

They do have a monopoly on a lot of great acts, but if the act you're hoping to see is playing anyplace else, go there instead.  No alcohol. Uncomfortable seating. No space for dancing! They over-sell their shows. I've seen little old ladies forced to jockey for standing room in the back of the "theater." There's also a long line to get in before the show starts. Able-bodied audience members only, please! And - it's not a coffeehouse! When is it EVER open except for when people are performing?  People go here for the great performers, but I don't understand the genuine affection a lot of people hold for this place.UPDATE:And now they're taking over the downtown Berkeley Capoeira studio, which was a thriving, all-day, all-ages community center. Like downtown Berkeley needs yet another place that targets white, boomer clientele. I'm disgusted with the City of Berkeley for letting the capoeira studio go.  Well, the good news is that the Freight and Salvage will be allowing alcohol at their shows, but supposedly only at intermission. Fortunately there are bars all over the neighborhood.

I've just been to open-mic night - it was friendly, down-to-earth, disorganized, had some hippy crap but also some decent stuff....  It's exactly what I'd expected from a non-profit coffeehouse in Berkeley.  (Comes completes with begging crackheads outside after the show.)  I'll definitely go back to the open-mic - and if you stay til the end, you get free tickets to shows.Wayyy better than fancy, tightly-run venues in SF, in my opinion.  :)

i love the freight!  it feels like a home, a musical home away from home, to me.  i give them four stars because they regularly feature musicians that i really want to go see, folks that don't turn up at other places and who i love-- Patty Larkin (witty modern folk/rock), Mike Marshall and Hamilton de Holanda (mandolin masters), Chris Smither (acoustic blues), Mary Gauthier (singer/songwriter of spare songs that quietly break you heart.)folks there are warm and welcoming, and the sound is pretty darn good.they are just affordable enough for me to keep going back: $15 to $30 for an open seating ticket.  they are just accessible enough, too-- no steps, and with rows of armless chairs that can be moved around to maximize seating room.  that said, those chairs aren't very comfortable and need an upgrade!they cheerfully sell bottled water and soda, cookies, snacks and coffee/tea.  there's also water available for free in cups, which i appreciate.sometimes there's an uptight "eco-elite" crowd in the audience, who push all my buttons and make me cranky.  management not responsible, i'm sure!i look forward to seeing their new digs when they move.  i hope it's even more accessible and a more comfortable venue.

My girlfriend takes me here for shows on a semi-regular basis, for which I feel pretty lucky. It's unique among music venues in the bay area, for sure. Where the hell else can you see Chris Smither AND mandolin master Hamilton de Holanda? And while rubbing shoulders with the Berkeley's eco-elite, no less. That's the downside. The crowd varies from show to show, sometimes it's fine and sometimes I feel slightly uncomfortable surrounded by all the thin healthy white people. Your  mileage may vary.The seating is about 75% armless, movable chairs. Which is especially nice if you're on the wider end of the spectrum. You can be pretty comfy there, fat or thin. If you want to sit anywhere close to the front. you need to get there seriously early and line up ouside. I recommend bringing a chair for this activity. Perhaps your submissive can take the chairs back to the car after you've gone in to get the good seats. If you show up later, you will definitely be sitting in the back. Which is pretty ok, as long as you're not on the part of the floor that slants backward.  Yeah, the space could use some work, but they're moving soon to a new location, I hear. Fat friendly rating: 4 stars.

This is a great coffee house. Acoustics aren't top top notch, but what the heck, it's a coffee house! I saw Ellis Paul and Antje Duvekot here, and their vocals blew me away, who needs Bose?The space is very homey. Unpretentious. Good, mellow crowd. And spacious, not like Postcrypt (bonus points to those who know what I'm talking about!)

One of the last best places to make a true connection with the people who create our musical history, both past and future.  This is my home away from home, I always feel like I'm heading across the Bay to my other living room to get cozy with the people whose music I have loved or grown up with or just discovered or haven't heard yet.  Where else can you wait on line for the bathroom with the All-Ireland Championship fiddler (Liz Carroll), or shoot the shit with Ramblin' Jack Elliot while he changes his socks, or have conversations with any of the performers while they're on stage 6 feet away from you, right in the middle of a set?  Only at the Freight.  And to top it off, the tea's organic, the vegan cookies are the size of your head, and you can dance in the aisle by yourself if you feel like it (well, ok, it IS Berkeley, you can pretty much do that anywhere, but it really is cool with everyone here).  I love it here, it is truely home-sweet-musical-home.

Great history.  Good acoustics.  Good booking.  And yes, a decent sound system, but I was at a good show Thursday night with a 13 piece band that was seriously flawed for me because the manager of the Freight and Salvage had gone and hired an incompetent sound guy.  How can you hire a sound guy who doesn't know what he's doing (and shows up 1 1/2 hours late for sound check, from what I heard from the musicians) for a 13 piece band?  That makes no sense, unless you just don't give a crap about the bands that you book.  I'd like to give 1 star for this, but again, this place does book some great acts, and hopefully the manager has better sense than to ruin good bands' shows by hiring terrible sound guys on a regular basis...

Great ecclectic set of talented artists, friendly crew, fine sound system.  Okay, so it doesn't have a very intimate feel (I agree with the "barn" description of another poster), and the chairs feel like, well, folding chairs.  And yeah, there's no alcohol sold but, sheesh people, must y'all drink *every time* you go out?  Have a coffee or juice fer cryin' out loud and just enjoy a natural mellow without the booze and whine, eh? ;)Other stuff:  easy parking, reasonable ticket prices, not far from the freeway if I remember correctly and not too hard to get to via public transit.

This place has history for me and my family.  My dad is the beacon of Bluegrass in our family.  He brought my sister and I to many performances at the Freight.  My sister actually met her husband at the Freight.  He was playing guitar for Frank Wakefield at the time and now they are married with 2 kids.  I took my husband on our first date to the Freight to see one of my favorite Bluegrass bands: Dry Branch Fire Squad.  First dates need alcohol and knowing that the Freight only serves coffee, we hit Lanesplitters pizza right around the corner first and had some excellent pizza and just the right amount of beer.  It obviously all worked out for us.  I even volunteered for them for awhile and got to hear some wonderful folk music for free and give back a little to a place that had given my family so much over the years.  You can't beat it!

Five Stars - for sticking to their vision since 1968. From the website: "The Freight & Salvage Coffee House is a nonprofit community arts organization dedicated to promoting public awareness and understanding of traditional music -- music that is rooted in and expressive of the great variety of regional, ethnic, and social cultures of peoples throughout the world. " While it looks like somebody's converted garage and the seating is not great, the sound system is excellent and the range and type of performers are (literally) all over the map. (Note - They're moving to a location near or next to the Berkeley Rep. theatre.)

I heard about Freight & Salvage when saw a friend's Mizrahi band play there. It's a great venue for hearing music you may never have heard of before. They are planning to move closer to downtown (near the theaters on Addison) so keep your eyes open for that.

Ok look. I was in a bad mood when I got here because I had been on what might be one of my most spectacularly bad dates ever (he lived with his sister who worked for Haven Humane Society & he told me that the only humor in their house involved animal euthenasia jokes, NO I AM NOT MAKING THAT UP PEOPLE!) I told him I had forgotten that it was my friends Birthday and hightailed it outta there.And ended up here. Where there was no alcohol to ease my worldly pain. Ok, why don't you people serve alcohol here? What are the alcoholics supposed to do? I'm not saying I'm an alcoholic, and I'm not saying that I can't enjoy music without it....but on this particular occassion I couldn't (on account of the crazy animal hater date)The music (Kiki Smith) was good, very innovative. Not really a fan of the folding chairs, but I like the barn atmosphere. That's really the most accurate description. Like you're at a concert in a barn. Because you are. And they don't serve alcohol. So it's like you're at a concert with the amish.Yeah, it's like that.Sorry. I was in a bad mood. I support the local music scene, I swear.I support it more when they serve alcohol there though.

The Freight and Salvage is a very low-key place to see acoustic music.  It's BYOB---well, they don't sell alcohol and probably don't want you bringing in your own, but I have great memories of sneaking in a nalgene full of wine (one of the clear ones... we didn't really think it through) and proceeding to get crazy.  There's something just a little too staid and grown-up about their sit-down folky shows.  I gotta give props to those individuals who don't care (or don't seem to realize?) that they are at a seated show, and dance up and down the aisles on acid or whatever.  That's what I would do if I had the balls. P.S.---Why is Yelp telling me that I might also consider the Bamboo Hut?  I can't think of anything else further from the Freight and Salvage...

Why didn't I know about this place in time to catch Willy Porter? Willy, please tell me you will return, not just to the Bay Area, but to Freight and Salvage. Because this place rocks! And folks. And blueses. OK, now I'm just making up words. But they deserve it. You can't help but feel at home here. It's like your friend set up a stage in his barn (if you happen to have a friend who has a barn.) The sound quality is fabulous. I wish they had espresso drinks but I suppose that horrible milk-steaming sound would distract from the great music.

The Freight and Salvage is the #1 Bay Area stop on the Folk Music and bluegrass circuit. The performers on this circuit are rarely household names, but some world class songwriters and pickers turn up regularly. Loudon Wainright, Cheryl Wheeler, Eliza Gilkyson, Tracy Grammer, Ralph Stanley, David Grisman, Mike Marshall are pretty well known in the folk world. And some outsanding lesser knowns like Harry Manx, Vance Gilbert and Claudia Russell have performed some really great shows there.Open mics a couple of times a month draw the local singer-songwriter crowd and give them a place to get their feet wet on a professional stage.

Truly a local (national?) treasure. Down home, no frills attraction for some of the best folk, bluegrass, and other distincly American genre musicians. Obviously the artists love playing there and that joy is shared by the audience. Most times the artists will hang out afterwards to sign CDs and share a cup of tea or the like. Have seen many great concerts there and would recommend it to like minded music lovers everywhere!
Metadata: {"YelpName": "Freight & Salvage Coffeehouse", "AuthorName": "Eric P.", "AuthorLocation": "Hollywood Hills West, Los Angeles, CA"}

ReviewContent: All acoustic music, for about $20 and a place to sit down. What could possibly be better? One of my favorite music venues.  They are dry (no booze), so only get to listen to the music...
